messageBody:
[Read_Alphabet] Re: New member: Read_Alphabet
I'd like to ask everyone in this group if they find QS to be
practical for transcribing speech.  Is anyone proficient enough to
record conversations on the street?  I just as soon prefer not to
learn Pitman shorthand.



 Your question has several interpretations.

1) Can you use QS for taking dictation?

I think you can. In fact, your question has inspired me to change my training strategy from just transliterating texts, to taking dictation.  I now record several paragraphs of the text on my pocket recorder and play it back while writing QS.  (At first you'd think knowing the text up front is cheating - but believe me, there is still plenty to learn by this process.) Also one begins to grasp whole words in QS, as opposed to linking sounds like pearls on a string.

2) Can you take down people's accents, as Professor Higgins did in My Fair Lady?

I say no.  Higgins was using Bell's Visible Speech, which recognized many more phonemes than the 40 allotted to QS.  Today he would use IPA.

Pitman, as I understand it, is not a phoneme-based shorthand, but merely a means of taking dictation, an art that, anyway, was made obolete by the Dictaphone.

Shaw did all of his writing in Pittman (which probably accounts for the long-winded, oratorical prose style he was prone to), and he had a noble secretary who transcribed all his drafts into good old Roman typewriting.  One of Shaw's goals in commissioning Shavian was to make a system easier to learn than Pittman, as well as one based on good phonemics. He was happy to leave the recording of accents and speech variations to the experts.
